018package org.apache.hadoop.hbase.util;
019
020import java.io.File;
021import java.io.IOException;
022import org.apache.hadoop.hbase.HBaseClassTestRule;
023import org.apache.hadoop.hbase.HBaseCommonTestingUtility;
024import org.apache.hadoop.hbase.testclassification.MediumTests;
025import org.apache.hadoop.hbase.testclassification.MiscTests;
026import org.apache.kerby.kerberos.kerb.KrbException;
027import org.apache.kerby.kerberos.kerb.server.SimpleKdcServer;
028import org.junit.ClassRule;
029import org.junit.Test;
030import org.junit.experimental.categories.Category;
031
032@Category({ MiscTests.class, MediumTests.class })
033public class TestSimpleKdcServerUtil {
034  @ClassRule
035  public static final HBaseClassTestRule CLASS_RULE =
036    HBaseClassTestRule.forClass(TestSimpleKdcServerUtil.class);
037  private static final HBaseCommonTestingUtility UTIL = new HBaseCommonTestingUtility();
038
039  /**
040   * Test we are able to ride over clashing port... BindException.. when starting up a kdc server.
041   */
042  @Test
043  public void testBindException() throws KrbException, IOException {
044    SimpleKdcServer kdc = null;
045    try {
046      File dir = new File(UTIL.getDataTestDir().toString());
047      kdc = SimpleKdcServerUtil.getRunningSimpleKdcServer(dir,
048        HBaseCommonTestingUtility::randomFreePort, true);
049      kdc.createPrincipal("wah");
050    } finally {
051      kdc.stop();
052    }
053  }
054}
